evidence: On March 5, 2025 the Texas A&M Queer Empowerment Council (QEC), a student organization at Texas A&M University, filed a civil‑rights complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.

The complaint alleges that, in official capacities, members of the Board of Regents of the Texas A&M University System, the university’s Chancellor and President, violated the First Amendment by adopting and enforcing a “drag‑ban” resolution on February 28, 2025.
The resolution prohibited all drag shows on campus, citing concerns that such events “promote gender ideology” and “demean women,” and invoked a federal executive order on gender ideology.
The QEC had already reserved the Rudder Theatre for its annual Draggieland drag show, scheduled for March 27, 2025, and had sold tickets when the ban was enacted.

The QEC’s suit is grounded in 42 U.S.C. §§ 1983 and 1988 and the Declaratory Judgment Act, alleging viewpoint discrimination, prior restraint, and violation of the Texas Education Code’s free‑speech provisions.
The plaintiff seeks declaratory relief, a permanent injunction preventing enforcement of the ban, and injunctive relief allowing Draggieland to proceed.
The suit also alleges a violation of the Texas Open Meetings Act because the Board failed to provide 72 hours’ notice before the special meeting that adopted the resolution.
Judge Lee H. Rosenthal granted the QEC’s motion for a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction on March 24, 2025.

The order enjoins the Board, Chancellor, and President from enforcing the drag‑ban resolution, requires the QEC to hold the Draggieland event on March 27, 2025 in the Rudder Theatre, and voids the resolution under the Texas Open Meetings Act.
The injunction remains in effect until further order.
On March 28, 2025 the defendants filed a notice of appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, challenging the preliminary injunction.
The appeal is pending.
No settlement or monitoring agreement has been entered into.
The court’s orders affirm that the ban was unconstitutional, constituting viewpoint discrimination and a prior restraint that infringes the QEC’s First‑Amendment rights.
extracted.value: The case involves the Texas A&M Queer Empowerment Council filing a civil‑rights complaint on March 5, 2025 alleging that the Board of Regents, Chancellor and President adopted a drag‑ban resolution on February 28, 2025 that prohibited all drag shows on campus, citing concerns that such events “promote gender ideology” and “demean women” and invoking a federal executive order on gender ideology; the QEC had already reserved the Rudder Theatre for its Draggieland event on March 27, 2025 and sold tickets when the ban was enacted; the lawsuit, grounded in 42 U.S.C. §§ 1983 and 1988 and the Declaratory Judgment Act, alleges viewpoint discrimination, prior restraint, violations of the Texas Education Code and the Texas Open Meetings Act for failing to provide 72 hours’ notice, and seeks declaratory relief, a permanent injunction preventing enforcement of the ban, and injunctive relief allowing Draggieland to proceed; the court granted a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction on March 24, 2025, enjoining enforcement of the resolution, requiring the QEC to hold Draggieland on March 27, 2025 in the Rudder Theatre and voiding the resolution under the Texas Open Meetings Act; the defendants filed an appeal on March 28, 2025, the appeal is pending, no settlement has been entered into, and the court’s orders affirm that the ban was unconstitutional, constituting viewpoint discrimination and a prior restraint that infringes the QEC’s First‑Amendment rights.

The suit alleges that EPA, acting in its official capacity, unlawfully froze the Greenhouse‑Gas Reduction Fund (GGRF) grant funds that EPA was required to allocate under the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 and that it subsequently attempted to terminate Inclusiv’s Clean Communities Investment Accelerator (CCIA) award.
Inclusiv received a $1.87 billion CCIA award on August 8 2024 and had been planning to distribute the funds to 108 credit‑union subrecipients.
On February 11 2025 EPA issued a notice of freeze, preventing Citibank (the designated financial agent) from disbursing the grant funds.
On March 11 2025 EPA sent a termination letter, which would have revoked Inclusiv’s award and returned the entire balance to the Treasury.
Citibank has refused to open subrecipient accounts or disburse funds, citing EPA’s instructions, and has not complied with Inclusiv’s lawful requests.
The court granted the TRO, ordering EPA and Citibank to restore the frozen funds to Inclusiv’s Citibank account.
The preliminary‑injunction motion was denied on April 16 2025.
On April 15 2025 the court consolidated this case with case 25‑cv‑698, citing common questions of law and fact, and all pleadings thereafter are to be filed in the lead case.
The proceedings are overseen by Judge Tanya S. Chutkan.
The complaint is grounded in the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 701‑706, asserting that EPA’s actions are “arbitrary, capricious, and not in accordance with law.”

The plaintiff also alleges violations of the Inflation Reduction Act, the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act, the Anti‑Deficiency Act, EPA regulations, and several constitutional provisions (separation of powers, due process, and the Take‑Care and Spending Clauses).

Inclusiv seeks declaratory relief that EPA’s freeze and termination are unlawful, injunctive relief to restore the frozen funds and prevent further EPA or Citibank interference, and enforcement of the Account Control Agreement that obligates Citibank to disburse the funds per Inclusiv’s instructions. No monetary damages are requested.
extracted.value: The case involves a complaint filed by Inclusiv, Inc. on March 31 2025 against the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin, Acting Deputy Administrator W.C. McIntosh, and Citibank, N.A., alleging that EPA unlawfully froze the Greenhouse‑Gas Reduction Fund (GGRF) grant funds and attempted to terminate Inclusiv’s Clean Communities Investment Accelerator (CCIA) award. The factual basis is supported by the notice of freeze issued by EPA on February 11 2025 preventing Citibank from disbursing the grant funds, the termination letter sent by EPA on March 11 2025, Citibank’s refusal to open subrecipient accounts or disburse funds, and the court’s TRO ordering restoration of the frozen funds to Inclusiv’s Citibank account. Background information includes Inclusiv’s receipt of a $1.87 billion CCIA award on August 8 2024 and its plan to distribute the funds to 108 credit‑union subrecipients, the legal claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and other statutes, and the procedural history of the case, including the denial of a preliminary injunction on April 16 2025, consolidation with case 25‑cv‑698 on April 15 2025, and oversight by Judge Tanya S. Chutkan.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: The summary provides clear facts: the filing date, parties, dates and nature of SEVIS terminations, the plaintiffs' allegations, the relief sought, the defendants, the court's orders (TRO, preliminary injunction, appeal), the case type, and the factual basis. evidence: On April 11 2025 the five plaintiffs—four current F‑1 international students and one former student now working under post‑graduate Optional Practical Training—filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California (San Jose Division).

They allege that the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) terminated their Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) records on April 4–8 2025 without lawful authority, relying on a generic "Otherwise Failing to Maintain Status" code that cited a criminal‑records check, although none of the plaintiffs had any criminal conduct that would constitute a failure to maintain F‑1 status.

The plaintiffs contend that the terminations were arbitrary, capricious, and violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgment Act, and that they also deprived the plaintiffs of their Fifth‑Amendment right to due process.

They seek a declaration that the terminations were unlawful, a vacatur of the SEVIS terminations and restoration of their F‑1 status, injunctive relief preventing arrest, detention, transfer, or removal, and reasonable costs and attorney fees.

The defendants sued in their official capacities are Secretary of DHS Kristi Noem, Acting Director of ICE Todd M. Lyons, Acting Field Office Director of ICE Moises Becerra, and President Donald J. Trump.
Because the plaintiffs feared retaliation, they filed a motion to proceed pseudonymously, which the court granted on April 17 2025.

That same day Judge Noel Wise granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and set a briefing schedule, ordering the defendants not to arrest, detain, transfer, or remove the plaintiffs for 14 days. The TRO also required the defendants to redact plaintiffs’ identifying information and prohibited the disclosure of any personal data beyond what is necessary for the litigation.

Judge White scheduled a preliminary‑injunction hearing for May 13 2025 and, on May 22 2025, granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, which imposes similar prohibitions on enforcement actions and protects the plaintiffs’ status pending the final decision.
The defendants appealed the preliminary injunction to the Ninth Circuit on July 21 2025, challenging the court’s orders.

The plaintiffs’ complaint is not a class action; it involves individual claims. The case is related to the earlier action 25‑cv‑03140‑JSW (Doe v. Trump) but has not been consolidated. No settlement has been reached, and no court‑enforced monitoring order exists.

The factual basis of the case centers on the abrupt, unwarranted termination of SEVIS records that deprived the plaintiffs of lawful F‑1 status and exposed them to potential arrest, detention, transfer, and removal.
extracted.value: The case involves five international students who filed a complaint on April 11 2025 alleging that DHS and ICE terminated their SEVIS records on April 4–8 2025 without lawful authority, based on a generic 'Otherwise Failing to Maintain Status' code citing a criminal‑records check despite no criminal conduct. The plaintiffs, four current F‑1 students and one former student on OPT, claim the terminations were arbitrary, capricious, violated the APA and Declaratory Judgment Act, and deprived them of Fifth Amendment due process. They seek a declaration of unlawful terminations, vacatur and restoration of F‑1 status, injunctive relief preventing arrest, detention, transfer or removal, and costs and attorney fees. Defendants include Secretary of DHS Kristi Noem, Acting Director of ICE Todd M. Lyons, Acting Field Office Director of ICE Moises Becerra, and President Donald J. Trump. The court granted a TRO on April 17 2025, a preliminary injunction on May 22 2025, and the defendants appealed to the Ninth Circuit on July 21 2025. The complaint is individual, not a class action, related to but not consolidated with case 25‑cv‑03140‑JSW, and no settlement or monitoring order exists. The factual basis centers on the abrupt, unwarranted termination of SEVIS records that deprived the plaintiffs of lawful F‑1 status and exposed them to potential arrest, detention, transfer or removal.

evidence: The United States District Court for the District of Columbia entered a complaint on April 29, 2025 in case No. 1:25‑cv‑01305, filed by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB), its Board of Directors, and three board members—Laura G. Ross, Thomas E. Rothman, and Diane Kaplan.

The defendants are Donald J. Trump in his official capacity as President of the United States, Trent Morse, the Deputy Director of Presidential Personnel, the United States Office of Management and Budget, Russell Vought, the Director of OMB, the White House Presidential Personnel Office, and Sergio Gor, the Director of the White House Presidential Personnel Office.
The plaintiffs allege that on April 28, 2025 an email purporting to terminate the three board members’ positions was sent by Trent Morse on behalf of the President.

The plaintiffs also invoke constitutional provisions—separation of powers, the Presentment Clause, the Appropriations Clause, and the Take‑Care Clause—to argue that the President’s action is ultra‑vires.

The requested relief is a declaratory judgment that the email has no legal effect and a preliminary injunction (later a temporary restraining order) preventing the defendants from giving effect to the purported removal or otherwise interfering with CPB’s governance.

Judge Randolph D. Moss, in a memorandum opinion and order dated June 8, 2025, denied the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, holding that the plaintiffs had failed to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits and a likelihood of irreparable harm.
Subsequent docket entries show voluntary dismissals of the individual claims of Laura Ross and Thomas Rothman, but no settlement, decree, or monitoring order has been entered.

evidence: In the United States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia, Charleston Division, plaintiff Harry Wiley, a coal‑mining electrician with a diagnosis of black lung, sued the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (DHS) on April 7, 2025.

Wiley filed a class‑action complaint on behalf of all miners in the district who have evidence of pneumoconiosis and who are eligible for the Coal Workers’ Health Surveillance Program (CWHSP) and the Part 90 job‑transfer program.

The complaint, supported by a private law firm, alleges that DHS’s abrupt termination of the Respiratory Health Division (RHD) at NIOSH on April 1, 2025—via a reduction‑in‑force notice issued March 27, 2025—violated the Coal Mine Health and Safety Act of 1969 (30 U.S.C. § 843) and its anti‑backsliding provision (30 U.S.C. § 811(a)(9)), the Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 706), and the Fifth Amendment’s due‑process clause.

Wiley seeks declaratory judgment and injunctive relief to restore the RHD, resume the CWHSP and Part 90 program, and compel DHS to provide the statutory medical screenings and job‑transfer rights that miners have earned.

After filing the amended complaint on April 21, 2025, Wiley moved for a preliminary injunction, arguing that the RHD closure caused irreparable injury by denying miners timely medical examinations and the right to transfer to low‑dust jobs.
DHS answered on June 16, 2025, and on May 1, 2025, filed motions to dismiss and to seal confidential attachments.
The court denied the dismissal motions and, after a hearing on May 7, 2025, issued a memorandum opinion and order on May 13, 2025 granting the preliminary injunction.

The injunction enjoins the RIFs in the RHD, requires full restoration of the division, mandates continued CWHSP and Part 90 operations, and directs the Secretary to certify compliance within twenty days.
The court set the security requirement at zero.
Subsequent to the injunction, Wiley filed a second amended complaint on July 9, 2025.
The court granted leave to file the second amended complaint on August 14, 2025, and issued a related order, terminating all moot motions and sealing attachments.
No settlement has been reached; the case remains pending, with the parties preparing for further discovery and potential trial.
The judge presiding over the matter is Judge Irene C. Berger.
extracted.value: The case involves plaintiff Harry Wiley filing a class‑action complaint on April 7, 2025, alleging that the Department of Health and Human Services abruptly terminated the Respiratory Health Division at NIOSH on April 1, 2025, violating the Coal Mine Health and Safety Act, its anti‑backsliding provision, the Administrative Procedure Act, and the Fifth Amendment. Wiley seeks declaratory judgment and injunctive relief to restore the RHD, resume the CWHSP and Part 90 program, and compel DHS to provide statutory medical screenings and job‑transfer rights to eligible miners. The court granted a preliminary injunction on May 13, 2025, enjoining the reduction‑in‑force, requiring restoration of the division, continuation of the programs, and directing the Secretary to certify compliance within twenty days. The court also set the security requirement at zero. Subsequent filings include a second amended complaint and related orders, with the case pending under Judge Irene C. Berger.

evidence: On May 17, 2025, Darwin Antonio Arevalo Millan, a Venezuelan citizen detained by ICE at the Desert View Annex, filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus and a class‑action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California.

The petition alleges that the President of the United States, together with the Attorney General, the Secretaries of Homeland Security, Defense, and State, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, and other government officials, unlawfully removed Arevalo and other Venezuelan nationals pursuant to Executive Order Proclamation No. 10903, which invokes the Alien Enemies Act (AEA).
The cause of action is a claim that the removal violates the Fifth‑Amendment right to due process.
Judge John W. Holcomb granted the petitioner’s application for a temporary restraining order and motion for class certification in part on May 19, 2025.
On June 2, 2025, the judge issued an amended order granting a preliminary injunction and class certification in part.
The defendants filed a notice of appeal to the Ninth Circuit on August 1, 2025.
The plaintiff’s counsel is private law firm SchroederLaw, represented by Joshua Jonathan Schroeder; the defendants are represented by government counsel. The case is a class action.
Related cases, including Trump v. J.G.G. and A.A.R.P. v. Trump, provide precedent on the enforceability of the proclamation and notice requirements for alien enemies.
extracted.value: The case involves Darwin Antonio Arevalo Millan, a Venezuelan citizen detained by ICE, who filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus and a class‑action complaint on May 17 2025, alleging unlawful removal under Executive Order Proclamation No. 10903 invoking the Alien Enemies Act; the petition is supported by the temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction issued by Judge John W. Holcomb on May 19 2025 and June 2 2025, the case is a Fifth‑Amendment due process claim and a class action, with background facts including the appeal filed on August 1 2025 and the precedent set by Trump v. J.G.G. and A.A.R.P. v. Trump.

evidence: On May 17, 2025, Darwin Antonio Arevalo Millan, a Venezuelan citizen detained by ICE at the Desert View Annex, filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus and a class‑action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California. The petition alleges that the President of the United States, together with the Attorney General, the Secretaries of Homeland Security, Defense, and State, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, and other government officials, unlawfully removed Arevalo and other Venezuelan nationals pursuant to Executive Order Proclamation No. 10903, which invokes the Alien Enemies Act (AEA). Arevalo seeks a preliminary injunction and a declaratory judgment to prevent the removal of himself and a putative class of Venezuelan detainees. The cause of action is a claim that the removal violates the Fifth‑Amendment right to due process. evidence: On May 22 2025, Shira Perlmutter, the Register of Copyrights and Director of the U.S. Copyright Office, filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. She alleged that President Donald J. Trump had unlawfully removed her from office by appointing Todd Blanche, the Deputy Attorney General, as acting Librarian of Congress and Paul Perkins as acting Register of Copyrights.

The complaint contends that the President’s actions violated the constitutional Appointments Clause and the statutory authority vested in the Librarian of Congress under 17 U.S.C. § 701(a) and 2 U.S.C. § 136.

The court denied both motions. The denial of the temporary restraining order was issued on May 28 2025; the denial of the preliminary injunction, along with a memorandum opinion, was issued on July 30 2025. The court held that Perlmutter had failed to demonstrate irreparable harm in the absence of injunctive relief. Judge Timothy J. Kelly presided over the case.

Following the denial, Perlmutter filed a notice of appeal with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit on July 31 2025. While the appeal is pending, she also filed an emergency motion for an injunction pending appeal on August 4 2025, which the court denied on August 20 2025.

No settlement has been reached, no injunctions or decrees have been issued, and no monitoring arrangements are in place. The case remains active in federal court, with the appellate panel yet to render a decision.
extracted.value: The case involves Shira Perlmutter, the Register of Copyrights, filing a complaint on May 22, 2025 alleging that President Donald J. Trump unlawfully removed her by appointing Todd Blanche as acting Librarian of Congress and Paul Perkins as acting Register of Copyrights. The complaint claims these actions violated the constitutional Appointments Clause and statutory authority under 17 U.S.C. § 701(a) and 2 U.S.C. § 136. Perlmutter’s counsel filed motions for a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction, both denied by Judge Timothy J. Kelly on May 28, 2025 and July 30, 2025, respectively, citing lack of irreparable harm. Perlmutter then filed an appeal on July 31, 2025, and an emergency motion for injunction pending appeal on August 4, 2025, which was denied on August 20, 2025. No settlement, injunctions, decrees, or monitoring arrangements have been issued, and the case remains active while the appellate panel awaits a decision.

evidence: The United States District Court for the District of Wyoming entered the action on April 20 2023 when Ashley and Sean Willey, parents and a teacher, filed a complaint against Sweetwater County School District No. 1 Board of Trustees, Superintendent Kelly McGovern, Assistant Superintendent Nicole Bolton, Director of Student Services Kayci Arnoldi, and Principal Bryant Blake.

Plaintiffs allege that the school district’s “Preferred Names and Parent‑Concealment Policy” required staff to use children’s chosen names and pronouns and to conceal from parents any student’s request to be treated as a different gender unless the child consented.

They claim the policy violates their fundamental parental rights to direct their children’s upbringing, medical and mental‑health decisions, and religious freedom, as well as the teacher’s First‑Amendment free‑speech rights.

Judge Scott W. Skavdahl issued an order on June 30 2023 granting the injunction in part: the district was enjoined from requiring staff to lie about a child’s gender identity or from precluding staff from responding to parents’ inquiries about the child’s name or pronoun.

Defendants filed a motion for summary judgment on March 24 2025. Judge Scott W. Skavdahl granted the motion on April 28 2025, dismissing plaintiffs on all remaining claims (Counts I, II, and III) and concluding the case in favor of the defendants.
Plaintiffs appealed the summary‑judgment order to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit on May 23 2025, filing a notice of appeal and preliminary record.
The policy’s content, including its impact on Willeys’ daughter, A.S., who has a history of trauma and a private treatment plan.
extracted.value: The case involves parents Ashley and Sean Willey filing a complaint on April 20 2023 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Wyoming against Sweetwater County School District No. 1 and its officials, alleging that the district’s “Preferred Names and Parent‑Concealment Policy” required staff to use children’s chosen names and pronouns and conceal parental requests regarding gender identity, thereby violating the Willeys’ parental rights, the teacher’s First‑Amendment free‑speech rights, and constitutional protections. A preliminary injunction was granted in part on June 30 2023, enjoining the district from requiring staff to lie about a child’s gender identity or preclude staff from responding to parents’ inquiries about the child’s name or pronoun. The defendants moved for dismissal and summary judgment, and the court granted summary judgment on April 28 2025, dismissing all remaining claims. The Willeys appealed the summary‑judgment order on May 23 2025. The policy’s impact on the Willeys’ daughter A.S., who has a history of trauma and a private treatment plan, is also a key background fact.

evidence: On May 10, 2016, a class‑action complaint was filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois (East St. Louis Division) by current and former residents of the Alexander County Housing Authority’s (ACHA) McBride and Elmwood public‑housing developments—most of whom are African American—against ACHA and its former executive directors James Wilson, Thomas Upchurch, Joanne Pink, and Martha Franklin.

The plaintiffs alleged that ACHA discriminated on the basis of race and familial status, maintained its McBride and Elmwood units in a state of disrepair, and overcharged residents in violation of the Fair Housing Act (42 U.S.C. § 3604), Title VI of the Civil Rights Act (42 U.S.C. § 2000d), the Illinois Civil Rights Act of 2003, and the Brooke Amendment to the U.S. Housing Act (42 U.S.C. § 1437a).
They sought declaratory and injunctive relief, damages for rent overcharges, and attorneys’ fees.

The case was initially assigned to Chief Judge Michael J. Reagan and later to Magistrate Judge Reona J. Daly. After filing amended complaints, engaging in discovery and settlement conferences, many plaintiffs withdrew or otherwise failed to prosecute their claims, and the court dismissed the action with prejudice on September 12, 2017, directing each party to bear its own attorneys’ fees and closing the case.
No trial, settlement, or decree resulted.

evidence: The United States filed an indictment on May 21, 2025 against a defendant of El Salvadorian origin, alleging he conspired to transport illegal aliens for financial gain and that he personally transported undocumented individuals for profit—charges under 8 U.S.C. § 1324(a)(1)(A)(v) and (ii) (conspiracy and actual smuggling).
The indictment was sealed at the government’s request and was unsealed on June 6, 2025 after the defendant was arrested in Nashville following his return from El Salvador.

The detention hearing was held on June 13, 2025. The judge ruled that the government had not met its burden under 18 U.S.C. § 3142(f) to justify a detention hearing—specifically, the government failed to show that the defendant’s alleged crimes involved a minor victim or posed a serious risk of flight or obstruction. Consequently, the judge denied the motion for detention and ordered the defendant’s release pending trial, subject to conditions to be set at a later hearing.
The judge scheduled a trial for January 27, 2026.
An order on August 22, 2025 released the defendant, incorporating the conditions outlined in the magistrate’s earlier orders (e.g., restrictions on contact with witnesses and monitoring).

Throughout the pre‑trial period, the court issued orders requiring the government to provide evidence in accordance with the Due Process Protections Act and to disclose materials under the Brady rule.

A magistrate judge ordered the government to comply with Brady discovery requirements on June 6 and, on June 12, directed the government to provide all discovery materials relevant to the detention hearing by that day.

evidence: On July 1, 2025, the City of Columbus, Ohio; the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, Maryland; the City of Chicago, Illinois; Doctors for America; and the Main Street Alliance filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland (Case 1:25‑cv‑02114‑BAH) against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), and Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. in his official capacity as Secretary of HHS.

The plaintiffs allege that CMS’s final rule, titled “Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act; Marketplace Integrity and Affordability” (the “2025 Rule”), violates the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and is contrary to law and arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).
The plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, specifically a stay of the rule’s effective date under 5 U.S.C. § 705 while the merits are decided.
The plaintiffs are individual plaintiffs; no class certification was pursued.
Their cause of action is based on the APA’s “unlawful and set‑aside” standard and the ACA’s statutory provisions governing guaranteed issue, renewability, and premium subsidies.
Judge Brendan A. Hurson presided over the case.
After the complaint, the parties filed motions for a stay, responses, and a hearing was held on August 14, 2025.

The court’s memorandum opinion (dated August 22, 2025) held that the plaintiffs had standing, that they likely would succeed on the merits for certain challenged provisions, and that they would suffer irreparable harm if the rule took effect.

The August 25, 2025 order clarified the stay: the effective dates of seven provisions of the 2025 Rule were stayed pending a final ruling on the merits—including the $5 premium penalty on automatic re‑enrollees, the revocation of guaranteed coverage for individuals with past‑due premiums, the failure‑to‑reconcile policy, special enrollment period verification, income‑inconsistency verification, changes to actuarial value ranges, and self‑attestation of projected income.  The stay did not apply to the rule’s change to the premium‑adjustment‑percentage methodology or to the elimination of the 60‑day extension for income‑verification.
No trial, settlement, or final decree has yet been entered.  The case remains pending on the court’s determination of the merits of the plaintiffs’ challenges.
extracted.value: The case involves a complaint filed on July 1, 2025 by the City of Columbus, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, City of Chicago, Doctors for America, and the Main Street Alliance against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, CMS, and Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., alleging that CMS’s 2025 Rule violates the Affordable Care Act and the Administrative Procedure Act; the plaintiffs, who are individual and did not pursue class certification, base their cause of action on the APA’s unlawful and set‑aside standard and the ACA’s statutory provisions governing guaranteed issue, renewability, and premium subsidies, and seek declaratory and injunctive relief, specifically a stay of the rule’s effective date; the case was heard by Judge Brendan A. Hurson, with a hearing on August 14, 2025; the court’s memorandum opinion dated August 22, 2025 found the plaintiffs had standing and likely would succeed on merits, and the August 25, 2025 order stayed the effective dates of seven provisions of the 2025 Rule pending a final ruling, while the stay did not cover certain methodology changes; the case remains pending.

These statements form the facts that support the plaintiffs' claim.

evidence: the Department’s March 28, 2025 rescission letter, which abruptly terminated all previously granted extensions of time to liquidate Education Stabilization Fund (ESF) awards, was arbitrary, capricious and contrary to the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).

The factual basis of the case is that the Department had granted the states extensions to liquidate hundreds of millions of dollars in COVID‑19 relief awards, and that the March 28 rescission letter, issued without notice and without a reasoned explanation, abruptly ended those extensions, causing the states to face potential funding gaps, program disruptions, and contractual obligations to vendors and staff.

evidence: On May 27, 2025, National Public Radio, Inc. and its local member stations—Roaring Fork Public Radio, Colorado Public Radio, and KSUT—filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald J. Trump (in his official capacity), the Office of Management and Budget, the Department of the Treasury, the National Endowment for the Arts, and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

The plaintiffs allege that on May 1, 2025 the President issued Executive Order 14290, “Ending Taxpayer Subsidization of Biased Media,” which directed the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) and all federal agencies to cease direct and indirect funding to NPR and PBS and to prohibit local public‑radio stations from using federal funds to acquire NPR programming.

The plaintiffs claim the order violates the First Amendment—by imposing viewpoint‑based discrimination and retaliation—and the Fifth Amendment’s due‑process clause, as well as the statutory framework of the Public Broadcasting Act (47 U.S.C. §§ 396, 398) and the National Foundation on the Arts and Humanities Act (20 U.S.C. § 954).
They seek declaratory and injunctive relief to block enforcement of the order and to preserve federal funding for NPR and its member stations.
Plaintiffs are represented by Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP, while the defendants are represented by attorneys from the Department of Justice.
Judge Randolph D. Moss presides over the case.
The complaint was joined by a related action, *Corporation for Public Broadcasting v. Trump* (No. 25‑cv‑1305).

The plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment (filed June 13, 2025) was accompanied by a petition for expedited briefing on June 10, 2025, and the defendants submitted a memorandum of law on July 12, 2025, arguing that the claims are not ripe and that the order is within the executive branch’s discretion. The plaintiffs responded with a combined opposition (July 25, 2025).
The court has granted motions for leave to appear pro hac vice, an expedited briefing schedule, and extensions of time, but no substantive ruling on the merits has yet been issued.
extracted.value: The case involves NPR and its member stations filing a complaint on May 27, 2025 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald J. Trump and several federal agencies, alleging that Trump issued Executive Order 14290 on May 1, 2025 that directed the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and all federal agencies to cease funding NPR and PBS and barred local public‑radio stations from using federal funds to obtain NPR programming. The plaintiffs claim the order violates the First Amendment, the Fifth Amendment’s due‑process clause, and statutes governing public broadcasting. They seek declaratory and injunctive relief to block enforcement of the order and preserve federal funding. Plaintiffs are represented by Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP; defendants by DOJ attorneys. Judge Randolph D. Moss presides. The complaint is joined by a related action, *Corporation for Public Broadcasting v. Trump* (No. 25‑cv‑1305). Procedurally, plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment on June 13, 2025 with an expedited briefing petition on June 10, 2025; defendants filed a memorandum on July 12, 2025, and plaintiffs filed a combined opposition on July 25, 2025. The court has granted leave to appear pro hac vice, an expedited briefing schedule, and extensions of time, but has not yet ruled on the merits.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the key factual elements—complaint filing date, parties, allegations, relief sought, injunction, appeal, and stay—by scanning the summary for dates, named entities, and legal claims. These elements constitute the factual basis of the case.

evidence: On April 3, 2025, the American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE), the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), the National Nurses Organizing Committee/National Nurses United (NNOC/NNU), the Service Employees International Union (SEIU), the National Association of Government Employees (NAGE), and the National Federation of Federal Employees (NFFE) filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, Oakland Division. These unions sued President Donald J. Trump in his official capacity as President, the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM), and dozens of federal agencies and their heads—most notably the Departments of State, Defense, Treasury, Veterans Affairs, Justice, Health and Human Services, Homeland Security, Interior, Energy, Agriculture, Environmental Protection Agency, International Trade Commission, General Services Administration, Social Security Administration, Labor, Housing and Urban Development, Transportation, and Education, along with their senior officials. The complaint alleges that Executive Order 14,251, issued by Trump on March 27, 2025, unlawfully excluded a broad array of agencies from the FSLMRS under 5 U.S.C. § 7103(b)(1) and that the order was motivated by retaliation against the plaintiffs’ First‑Amendment‑protected speech and petitioning. The plaintiffs argue that the order was ultra‑vires, violated the Fifth‑Amendment procedural due process, abrogated property rights in collective‑bargaining agreements, and constituted unlawful equal‑protection discrimination. They seek declaratory and injunctive relief to restore union recognition, collective‑bargaining rights, dues deductions, and grievance procedures, as well as attorneys’ fees and costs.

Judge James Donato, after reviewing the complaint and the plaintiffs’ ex‑parte motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction filed on April 7, 2025, issued a preliminary injunction on June 24, 2025. The injunction enjoins all named agencies and agency heads from implementing or enforcing Section 2 of Executive Order 14,251, requires them to maintain existing collective‑bargaining agreements, preserve dues deductions, and continue to provide official time and office space to unions. The order remains in effect pending further court action.

On June 26, 2025, the defendants filed a notice of appeal to the Ninth Circuit. The U.S. Court of Appeals granted an administrative stay of the injunction on July 10, 2025, pending a ruling on the appeal. The preliminary injunction’s terms, including the prohibition against terminating CBAs and the requirement to maintain union dues, remain in effect until the appellate court issues a final decision. No settlement or monitoring order has been entered. The case centers on the constitutionality of a broad executive action that the plaintiffs contend was a retaliatory, overbroad use of national‑security authority that stripped federal workers of their collective‑bargaining rights.
extracted.value: The case involves a complaint filed on April 3, 2025, by a coalition of unions against President Donald J. Trump, the U.S. Office of Personnel Management, and dozens of federal agencies, alleging that Executive Order 14,251 unlawfully excluded agencies from the Federal Service Labor Management Relations Statute and was motivated by retaliation. The complaint claims the order was ultra‑vires, violated Fifth‑Amendment procedural due process, abrogated property rights in collective‑bargaining agreements, and constituted unlawful equal‑protection discrimination. The plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief to restore union recognition, collective‑bargaining rights, dues deductions, and grievance procedures, plus attorneys’ fees and costs. Judge James Donato issued a preliminary injunction on June 24, 2025, enjoining agencies from implementing the order and requiring maintenance of CBAs and dues deductions. The injunction remains pending while the defendants appeal, with a stay granted on July 10, 2025. The factual basis centers on the constitutionality of the executive order as a retaliatory, overbroad use of national‑security authority that stripped federal workers of collective‑bargaining rights.

evidence: The case was filed on July 21, 2025, in the United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island.

The plaintiffs are a coalition of nonprofit organizations that provide services to victims of domestic violence, sexual assault, and homelessness, including the Rhode Island Coalition Against Domestic Violence, the California Partnership to End Domestic Violence, the Colorado Coalition Against Sexual Assault, the District of Columbia Coalition Against Domestic Violence, the End Abuse Wisconsin coalition, the Idaho Coalition Against Sexual and Domestic Violence, the Iowa Coalition Against Domestic Violence, Jane Doe Inc., the Massachusetts Coalition Against Sexual Assault and Domestic Violence, the Kansas Coalition Against Sexual and Domestic Violence, the Montana Coalition Against Domestic and Sexual Violence, the North Carolina Coalition Against Domestic Violence, the Oregon Coalition Against Domestic and Sexual Violence, the Pennsylvania Coalition Against Domestic Violence, ValorUS, Violence Free Minnesota, the Virginia Sexual and Domestic Violence Action Alliance, the Wisconsin Coalition Against Sexual Assault, House of Hope Community Development Corporation, the Rhode Island Coalition to End Homelessness, Community Care Alliance, Foster Forward, and Haus of Codec.

The defendants are federal officials and agencies: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in his official capacity as Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services; the Department of Health and Human Services; Andrew Gradison, Acting Assistant Secretary of the Administration for Children and Families; the Administration for Children and Families; Susan Monarez, Acting Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; Thomas J. Engels, Administrator of the Health Resources & Services Administration; the Health Resources & Services Administration; Scott Turner, Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development; and the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

The plaintiffs allege that, following a series of executive orders issued by the President, HUD and HHS have imposed new funding conditions on federal grant programs—including Continuum of Care, Community Development Block Grant, Emergency Solutions Grant, and various HHS programs such as the Family Violence Prevention Services Act and the Violence Prevention Program that require grantees to certify they do not promote “gender ideology,” to certify that they do not operate programs that advance diversity, equity, inclusion, or “discriminatory equity ideology,” and to certify that they will not use grant funds to promote elective abortion.
The plaintiffs argue these conditions are not authorized by Congress, are vague, and chill protected speech and other constitutional rights.
They seek declaratory and injunctive relief to set aside the new conditions and prevent their enforcement.

The action is brought under the Administrative Procedure Act for exceeding statutory authority, acting contrary to law, arbitrarily and capriciously, and for violating the First Amendment and the Fifth Amendment due process clause, as well as for infringing the separation of powers and the Spending Clause.

On July 28, 2025, Judge DuBose granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO), ordering HUD and HHS not to enforce the new funding conditions on the plaintiffs’ grant programs and requiring compliance within 24 hours.
The TRO was amended on August 7, 2025, expanding the list of plaintiffs covered and clarifying the scope of the injunction.

evidence: The factual basis of the dispute is that the Silver Consolidated Schools had received a $6 million grant to expand school‑based mental‑health services, including the hiring of seven new professionals and the creation of wellness rooms and a mobile app.
On April 29, 2025 the Department terminated the grant, citing a shift in administrative priorities, thereby depriving the district of essential mental‑health resources.
The plaintiffs argue that the termination is arbitrary, capricious, and unconstitutional, and that the Department’s DCL and “End DEI” portal constitute unlawful threats of funding withdrawal.

The complaint seeks declaratory and injunctive relief under 28 U.S.C. § 2201, alleging that the Department’s termination of a $6 million mental‑health grant—awarded under the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act (Pub. L. 117‑159, 163 Stat. 1313) and the federal statute 42 U.S.C. § 254c–19—violates statutory authority (5 U.S.C. § 702; 28 U.S.C. § 1331), the Spending Clause, and constitutional protections under the First and Fifth Amendments.

The complaint also challenges a Dear Colleague Letter issued February 14, 2025 and an “End DEI” portal, claiming they unlawfully threat to withhold federal funding for schools that provide diversity, equity, and inclusion programming.
extracted.value: The case involves the Silver Consolidated Schools receiving a $6 million mental‑health grant under the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act and 42 U.S.C. § 254c–19 to expand school‑based mental‑health services, including hiring seven new professionals, creating wellness rooms, and developing a mobile app; the Department terminated the grant on April 29, 2025 citing a shift in administrative priorities, depriving the district of essential resources; the plaintiffs claim the termination is arbitrary, capricious, and unconstitutional, and that the Department’s Dear Colleague Letter (issued February 14, 2025) and End DEI portal unlawfully threaten to withhold federal funding for schools that provide diversity, equity, and inclusion programming.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the key factual events, allegations, legal basis, defendants' opposition, court decisions, and overall impact from the case summary, extracting verbatim snippets that support each fact.

evidence: On March 31, 2025, the League of United Latin American Citizens, the Secure Families Initiative, and the Arizona Students’ Association filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia asserting that President Donald J. Trump’s Executive Order 14,248 unlawfully interfered with the federal election process.

The plaintiffs allege that the order directs the Election Assistance Commission (EAC) to add a documentary‑proof‑of‑citizenship requirement to the National Mail Voter Registration Form, compels the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of State to provide access to voter‑registration data, requires federal agencies to verify citizenship before issuing the form, and conditions federal funding on compliance with an election‑day‑receipt deadline.

The complaint bases its claim on the Constitution’s Elections Clause and separation‑of‑powers provisions, the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 (NVRA), the Help America Vote Act of 2002 (HAVA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA).
Plaintiffs seek declaratory relief and a preliminary injunction to halt implementation of the contested provisions.

Defendants—including the Executive Office of the President, the U.S. Election Assistance Commission, the Department of Justice, the Department of Defense, the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Department of the Interior, and the Small Business Administration—filed an opposition on April 14, 2025, arguing that the plaintiffs lack standing, the challenges are premature, and the order is consistent with applicable law.
The case was consolidated with two other suits brought by the Democratic National Committee and the League of Women Voters, making the docket 1:25‑cv‑00946‑CKK.

On April 24, 2025, Judge Colleen Kollar‑Kotelly issued a memorandum opinion and order.  The court granted the joint motion of the non‑partisan plaintiffs and the League plaintiffs to enjoin the EAC and its commissioners from implementing Section 2(a) of the order—that is, from adding the documentary‑proof‑of‑citizenship requirement to the federal voter‑registration form.  The court also granted, in part, the Democratic Party plaintiffs’ motion for Section 2(a) and, more narrowly, for Section 2(d), which requires federal agencies to assess citizenship before providing the form.  The court denied the plaintiffs’ request to enjoin Section 2(b) (the directive to DHS and the State Department to share voter‑registration data) as the request was deemed unripe.
The order effectively blocks the President’s attempt to alter the federal registration process and preserves the statutory framework established by Congress.
extracted.value: The case involves a complaint filed on March 31 2025 by the League of United Latin American Citizens, Secure Families Initiative, and Arizona Students’ Association alleging that President Donald J. Trump’s Executive Order 14,248 unlawfully interfered with the federal election process by directing the Election Assistance Commission to add a documentary‑proof‑of‑citizenship requirement to the National Mail Voter Registration Form, compels DHS and the State Department to provide voter‑registration data, requires federal agencies to verify citizenship before issuing the form, and conditions federal funding on an election‑day receipt deadline. The complaint cites the Constitution’s Elections Clause and separation‑of‑powers provisions, the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 (NVRA), the Help America Vote Act of 2002 (HAVA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA), and seeks declaratory relief and a preliminary injunction. Defendants opposed on April 14 2025 arguing lack of standing and that the order is consistent with law. The case was consolidated with suits by the Democratic National Committee and the League of Women Voters (docket 1:25‑cv‑00946‑CKK). Judge Colleen Kollar‑Kotelly on April 24 2025 granted an injunction against implementing Section 2(a) and part of Section 2(d) of the order, but denied injunction on Section 2(b), effectively blocking the President’s attempt to alter the federal registration process and preserving Congress’s statutory framework.

evidence: On April 28, 2025, the Washington State Association of Head Start and Early Childhood Education and Assistance Program, the Illinois, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin Head Start Associations, Family Forward Oregon, and Parent Voices Oakland filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.

Allegations include mass layoffs and the closure of half of the Office of Head Start’s regional offices, a freeze of federal funding that has left agencies unable to pay staff or sustain operations, and the issuance of a “March 14 DEI Letter” and an “April 16 DEIA Certification” that prohibit any activities that promote diversity, equity, inclusion, or accessibility.

Plaintiffs contend that these actions violate the Head Start Act’s mandates to provide culturally and linguistically appropriate services to diverse children and families, the constitutional separation‑of‑powers and spending clauses, the First Amendment, the Administrative Procedure Act, and the Rehabilitation Act.

The complaint was amended on May 13, 2025, and on May 16, 2025 the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction. Summonses were issued to the defendants in mid‑May, and the plaintiffs have received leave to appear pro hac vice on several occasions. Judge Ricardo S. Martinez has yet to rule on the motion for preliminary injunction, and no settlement or decree has been entered. The case remains pending.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by extracting the key events, claims, and procedural actions described in the summary, including the lawsuit filing, the statutory issue, the injunction, the U.S. intervention, and the current status.  These facts form the factual basis of the case.

evidence: In May 2025 the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Seattle, the Bishops of Yakima and Spokane, and several priests sued Washington state officials.  The plaintiffs—members of the clergy who, under their diocesan policies, are required to report suspected child abuse but have an exemption for information learned in confession—allege that Senate Bill 5375 (signed by Governor Robert Ferguson on May 2, 2025 and effective July 27, 2025) unlawfully forces them to break the sacramental seal and removes that exemption while leaving it for other professionals.  They bring nine causes of action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, claiming violations of the First Amendment’s Free‑Exercise and Establishment Clauses, the Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal‑Protection Clause, and Washington’s Constitution (Article I, § 11).  The remedy sought is declaratory and injunctive relief, specifically a preliminary injunction that would prevent the state from enforcing SB 5375 against the plaintiffs and all Roman Catholic priests in Washington who fall under their administration.

On June 5, 2025 the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction.  The court, Judge David G. Estudillo, held a hearing on July 14, 2025, and on July 18, 2025 issued an order granting the injunction.  The court enjoined enforcement of SB 5375 as it applies to the sacrament of confession for the plaintiffs and for all Roman Catholic priests in Washington who are under the administration of the plaintiffs’ dioceses.  The injunction does not address the plaintiffs’ other constitutional claims but preserves the status quo pending a final judgment.

On June 23, 2025 the United States intervened under 42 U.S.C. § 2000h‑2, filing a motion for preliminary injunction and a proposed complaint in intervention.  The court granted the U.S.’s motion to intervene on July 15, 2025, allowing the U.S. to seek relief in the same case.  The U.S. also filed a motion for a preliminary injunction on June 25, 2025 and the court scheduled a hearing for July 23, 2025.  The U.S. has requested the same injunctive relief as the plaintiffs, seeking to prevent enforcement of SB 5375 against clergy who learn abuse through confession.
No trial has occurred, and no settlement has been reached.  The case remains pending, with the preliminary injunction in effect for the period until the court issues a final judgment on the merits.
extracted.value: The case involves a lawsuit filed in May 2025 by the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Seattle, the Bishops of Yakima and Spokane, and several priests against Washington state officials, alleging that Senate Bill 5375, signed on May 2, 2025 and effective July 27, 2025, unlawfully forces them to break the sacramental seal and removes their exemption for information learned in confession.  They claim violations of the First Amendment, Fourteenth Amendment, and Washington Constitution, and seek a preliminary injunction.  The court granted such an injunction on July 18, 2025, enjoining enforcement of the bill for the sacrament of confession for these clergy.  The United States intervened on July 15, 2025, seeking the same relief.  The case remains pending with the injunction in effect until final judgment.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the key facts describing the complaint filing, alleged federalization, statutory claims, court orders, and current status.

evidence: On June 9, 2025 the State of California, through Governor Gavin Newsom, filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California (Case 3:25‑cv‑04870‑CRB) against President Donald J. Trump, Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth, and the U.S. Department of Defense.

The suit alleges that the defendants unlawfully federalized 4,000 California National Guard soldiers and deployed them to Los Angeles to assist U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) operations.

Plaintiffs contend that the federalization violated 10 U.S.C. § 12406, because the statutory predicates—“a rebellion or danger of rebellion” and “the President is unable with the regular forces to execute the laws”—were not present, and that the orders were not issued “through the governor” as required.

They also claim a Tenth‑Amendment violation, asserting that the federal use of the Guard usurped the state’s police powers, and a violation of the Posse Comitatus Act, arguing that the troops were engaged in civilian law‑enforcement duties.

The court held an ex‑parte hearing on June 12, 2025, and granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) that enjoined the defendants from deploying California National Guard troops in Los Angeles and directed them to return control of the Guard to Governor Newsom.

The defendants appealed the TRO and filed a motion for a stay pending appeal; the Ninth Circuit granted an administrative stay on June 19, 2025, while the preliminary‑injunction hearing remains scheduled for June 20, 2025.
extracted.value: The case involves the State of California filing a complaint on June 9, 2025 alleging that the federal government unlawfully federalized 4,000 California National Guard soldiers and deployed them to Los Angeles to assist ICE operations, violating 10 U.S.C. § 12406, the Tenth Amendment, and the Posse Comitatus Act; this claim is supported by the complaint, the ex‑parte temporary restraining order granted on June 12, 2025, and subsequent motions, with background information including the statutory predicates of 10 U.S.C. § 12406, the requirement that orders be issued through the governor, and the federal troops’ engagement in civilian law‑enforcement duties.

evidence: On March 25, 2025 the American Association of University Professors (AAUP) and the American Federation of Teachers (AFT) filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against a group of federal agencies—including the Department of Justice, Department of Education, Department of Health and Human Services, the National Institutes of Health, and the General Services Administration—and the officials who head those agencies (e.g., Attorney General Pamela Bondi, DOJ’s Leo Terrell, ED’s Linda McMahon, HHS’s Robert F. Kennedy Jr., NIH’s Matthew J. Memoli, and GSA’s Stephen Ehikian).

The complaint alleges that executive actions taken in March 2025 threatened to withhold about $400 million in federal research funding from Columbia University unless the university complied with a set of conditions that the plaintiffs say would suppress academic freedom and violate the First Amendment.

The plaintiffs also claim that the agencies failed to follow the procedural requirements of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) when terminating funding and imposing the conditions.
Plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction on April 3, 2025; the defendants filed an opposition memorandum of law on May 1, 2025.
On June 16, 2025 the court denied the injunction and dismissed the case for lack of standing.
The action was assigned to Judge Mary Kay Vyskocil.
extracted.value: The case involves a complaint filed on March 25, 2025 by the AAUP and AFT against a group of federal agencies and officials, alleging that executive actions threatened to withhold about $400 million in federal research funding from Columbia University unless the university complied with conditions that would suppress academic freedom and violate the First Amendment. The plaintiffs also claim procedural violations under Title VI and the APA. They sought a preliminary injunction to restore the terminated funds and prevent future denial of assistance. The court denied the injunction and dismissed the case for lack of standing. The action was assigned to Judge Mary Kay Vyskocil.

evidence: In March 2025 the plaintiffs—eight students who studied at Columbia University and Barnard College—filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York against Columbia University, Barnard, the Trustees of Columbia, the university’s interim president, the U.S. House Committee on Education and Workforce, and its chairman, Tim Walberg. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, allege that the Committee’s February 13, 2025 letter demanded that Columbia produce all disciplinary records relating to eleven student‑protest incidents and threatened to cut the university’s federal funding. The plaintiffs contend that this “jaw‑boning” coerces Columbia into suppressing protected speech and that the university’s compliance infringes the First Amendment. They seek declaratory and injunctive relief to bar the Committee and the university from further disclosure of student records.

The second complaint added federal defendants—Pam Bondi, Linda McMahon, Leo Terrell, Sean Keveney, and Josh Gruenbaum—arguing that the federal agencies’ March 13 letter demands (mask bans, policy receivership, and other administrative changes) also violate the First Amendment.
extracted.value: The case involves eight students from Columbia University and Barnard College who filed a complaint in March 2025 alleging that the U.S. House Committee on Education and Workforce’s February 13, 2025 letter demanded all disciplinary records related to eleven student‑protest incidents and threatened to cut the university’s federal funding, thereby coercing Columbia into suppressing protected speech and infringing the First Amendment; the plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief to bar further disclosure of student records. The plaintiffs also filed a second amended complaint adding federal defendants and alleging that the federal agencies’ March 13 letter demands—including mask bans, policy receivership, and other administrative changes—also violate the First Amendment.

evidence: A motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction was filed in mid‑March, but the court denied the TRO and vacated the temporary injunction, ordering that Columbia be enjoined from providing records only after a hearing on March 25. The court granted the plaintiffs leave to file a second amended complaint on April 18. The second complaint added federal defendants—Pam Bondi, Linda McMahon, Leo Terrell, Sean Keveney, and Josh Gruenbaum—arguing that the federal agencies’ March 13 letter demands (mask bans, policy receivership, and other administrative changes) also violate the First Amendment.

On May 23 the Congressional and federal defendants filed motions to dismiss. The court dismissed the plaintiffs’ claims against the Committee and its chairman on the basis of the Speech‑or‑Debate Clause and, on June 18, dismissed the individual federal defendants in their official capacities. Protective‑order proceedings were held in April, requiring all parties to keep confidential any identifying information about the plaintiffs.

The case remains pending on the plaintiffs’ remaining claims against Columbia University and Barnard, which allege that the university’s cooperation with the Committee and the federal agencies unlawfully coerced the institution into actions that chill protected speech. No settlement has been reached, and the court has yet to rule on the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction that seeks to prevent further disclosure of student records.
extracted.value: The court denied the TRO, vacated the temporary injunction, and ordered that Columbia be enjoined from providing records only after a hearing on March 25. The court granted leave to file a second amended complaint on April 18. The plaintiffs filed motions to dismiss; the court dismissed claims against the Committee and its chairman on the basis of the Speech‑or‑Debate Clause, and dismissed individual federal defendants in their official capacities on June 18. Protective‑order proceedings in April required all parties to keep identifying information about the plaintiffs confidential. The case remains pending on the plaintiffs’ remaining claims against Columbia University and Barnard, with no settlement reached and the court yet to rule on the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the core factual elements in the summary: the coalition of states filing a complaint, the March 27 Directive's consequences, the plaintiffs' claims and requested relief, the preliminary injunction and its scope, and the defendants' denied motions. These facts together establish the factual basis of the case.

evidence: In the United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island, a coalition of state governments—New York, Washington, Rhode Island, Arizona, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, the District of Columbia, Hawaii, Illinois, Maine, Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey, New Mexico, Oregon, Vermont, and Wisconsin—filed a complaint on May 5, 2025 against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and its senior officials.

The plaintiffs allege that HHS, under Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., unlawfully dismantled the agency by issuing a “March 27 Directive” that terminated 10,000 employees, reorganized HHS’s 28 divisions into 15, closed half of its regional offices, and created a new “Administration for a Healthy America.”

The stated relief is declaratory and injunctive: the injunction seeks to halt the March 27 Directive, reinstate terminated employees, and restore the statutory functions of the affected agencies (CDC, FDA, SAMHSA, ACF, ACL, and other HHS sub‑agencies).

The motion for a preliminary injunction was filed on May 9, 2025. Judge Melissa R. DuBose granted the injunction on July 1, 2025, enjoining HHS and the named officials from further implementing the March 27 Directive until the court’s order is modified.

The injunction covers specific agencies and programs, including the CDC’s National Center for HIV, Viral Hepatitis, STD, and Tuberculosis Prevention; the CDC’s Division of Reproductive Health; the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health; the FDA’s Center for Tobacco Products; the Office of Head Start and its regional staff; and the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation.
Defendants filed a motion to vacate the injunction and a motion for a stay pending appeal, both of which were denied on July 18, 2025.
extracted.value: The case involves a coalition of 19 states filing a complaint on May 5, 2025, alleging that HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. issued a March 27 Directive that terminated 10,000 employees, reorganized 28 divisions into 15, closed half of HHS’s regional offices, and created a new Administration for a Healthy America, violating constitutional separation of powers, the Appropriations Clause, and statutory authority. The plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief to halt the directive, reinstate employees, and restore statutory functions of agencies such as CDC, FDA, SAMHSA, ACF, ACL, and others. A preliminary injunction was granted on July 1, 2025, enjoining further implementation of the directive and covering agencies like CDC’s National Center for HIV, CDC’s Division of Reproductive Health, National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, FDA’s Center for Tobacco Products, Office of Head Start, and Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation. The defendants’ motions to vacate and stay were denied on July 18, 2025. The litigation centers on the legality of the workforce reductions and reorganization, with the court seeking to preserve statutory functions that the states rely on for public health and welfare.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: Reviewed the summary to identify the parties, timeline of AmeriCorps actions, legal claims, and court rulings, and extracted the key factual elements that form the basis of the case.

evidence: On April 29, 2025 the United States District Court for the District of Maryland received a complaint filed by the State of Maryland, the State of Delaware, the State of California, the State of Colorado, the State of Arizona, the State of Connecticut, the District of Columbia, the State of Hawai‘i, the State of Illinois, the Office of the Governor of Kentucky (ex rel. Andy Beshear), the State of Maine, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, the People of the State of Michigan, the State of Minnesota, the State of Nevada, the State of New Jersey, the State of New Mexico, the State of New York, the State of North Carolina, the State of Oregon, the State of Rhode Island, the State of Vermont, the State of Washington, and the State of Wisconsin.  The plaintiffs are the 24 states and the District of Columbia; the defendants are the Corporation for National and Community Service (“AmeriCorps”) and Jennifer Bastress Tahmasebi, AmeriCorps’ interim head.

On April 15, 2025 AmeriCorps notified all National Civilian Community Corps (NCCC) members that they would be released from service effective April 30.  On April 16, AmeriCorps placed approximately 85 % of its staff on administrative leave, and on April 24 it issued reduction‑in‑force notices that cut nearly 50 % of its remaining workforce.  On April 25, AmeriCorps terminated about $400 million of federal grants, ordered grantees to cease all award activities, and required the exit of all AmeriCorps and Volunteers in Service to America (VISTA) members.

The plaintiffs contend that AmeriCorps’ actions violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) because the agency failed to conduct the notice‑and‑comment rulemaking required by the 2024 and 2025 Appropriations Acts for any “significant changes” to its program requirements, service delivery, or policy.  They also claim that the actions were arbitrary and capricious, deprived the states of statutory grant funding, and violated the separation of powers by usurping Congress’s congressional budget authority.

Judge Deborah L. Boardman, hearing the case, granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction on June 5, 2025.  The injunction enjoined AmeriCorps and its interim head from executing the April 25 grant terminations, from terminating NCCC members, and required the parties to comply with the notice‑and‑comment requirement before making any further significant changes that harm the plaintiff states.  The court also ordered AmeriCorps to restore the affected programs and return the displaced volunteers.

On July 7, 2025 the defendants filed a motion to modify the injunction, citing the Supreme Court decision in *Trump v. CASA, Inc.* (2025) that federal courts cannot issue universal injunctions.  The court granted the motion and modified the injunction on July 10, 2025, limiting the notice‑and‑comment requirement to actions that affect the plaintiff states.  The injunction remains in effect, requiring AmeriCorps to restore the terminated grants and programs and to obtain proper notice and comment before any future significant changes.
extracted.value: The case involves AmeriCorps cutting its workforce, terminating volunteers and grants, closing more than 1,000 programs, and terminating $400 million of federal grants on April 25, 2025, after notifying NCCC members on April 15, placing 85 % of staff on administrative leave on April 16, and issuing reduction‑in‑force notices on April 24. The plaintiffs, 24 states and the District of Columbia, allege that these actions violated the Administrative Procedure Act, deprived the states of statutory grant funding, and usurped Congress’s budget authority. The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 5, 2025, and modified it on July 10, 2025, requiring AmeriCorps to restore programs and obtain proper notice‑and‑comment before future significant changes.

extracted.value: A complaint filed by the 24 states and the District of Columbia on April 29, 2025 alleging that AmeriCorps’ actions violated the APA and seeking declaratory relief, a preliminary injunction to prevent further dismantling, and restoration of terminated programs, grants, and volunteers.

evidence: Judge Deborah L. Boardman, hearing the case, granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction on June 5, 2025.

The injunction enjoined AmeriCorps and its interim head from executing the April 25 grant terminations, from terminating NCCC members, and required the parties to comply with the notice‑and‑comment requirement before making any further significant changes that harm the plaintiff states. The court also ordered AmeriCorps to restore the affected programs and return the displaced volunteers.

evidence: On July 7, 2025 the defendants filed a motion to modify the injunction, citing the Supreme Court decision in *Trump v. CASA, Inc.* (2025) that federal courts cannot issue universal injunctions.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by extracting statements that describe the lawsuit filing, the executive order, the DOJ/DOGE actions, the impact on IMLS staff and grants, and the statutory context under the MLS Act.

evidence: The lawsuit was filed on **April 7 2025** by the American Library Association (ALA) and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), AFL‑CIO, against a group of federal defendants that includes former President Donald Trump, Acting Director Keith Sonderling of the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS), the IMLS agency itself, the U.S. Department of Education’s “Department of Government Efficiency” (DOGE) and its temporary organization, the U.S. Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and its director Russell Vought, and Acting Administrator Amy GLEASON of the U.S. DOGE Service.

The plaintiffs seek to halt and reverse the executive‑order‑driven dismantling of IMLS, restore staff and grant funding, and compel the defendants to comply with the statutory mandates of the Museum and Library Services Act (MLS Act), the 2024–2025 Appropriations Acts, and other relevant federal statutes.

The plaintiffs argue that President Trump’s Executive Order 14238 (“Continuing the Reduction of the Federal Bureaucracy”) unlawfully directed the elimination of IMLS, and that the DOJ’s DOGE unit and OMB failed to uphold the statutes that create, fund, and govern IMLS.

They claim that the defendants’ actions—firing the 75‑person IMLS workforce, terminating state, tribal, and museum grants, and firing the National Museum and Library Services Board—violate Congress’s exclusive authority to establish and regulate federal agencies, and that such conduct deprives libraries, librarians, and the public of essential services and data.

The factual basis centers on the President’s executive order, the DOGE’s rapid staffing cuts and grant terminations, the resulting financial and operational harm to libraries nationwide, and the statutory requirement that IMLS award and manage federal grants and conduct data collection under the MLS Act.
extracted.value: The case involves the lawsuit filed on April 7 2025 by the American Library Association (ALA) and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), AFL‑CIO, against former President Donald Trump and other federal defendants, seeking to halt the executive‑order‑driven dismantling of the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS); this claim is supported by President Trump’s Executive Order 14238 directing the elimination of IMLS and the DOJ’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) and the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) failing to uphold statutes that create, fund, and govern IMLS; with background information such as the firing of the 75‑person IMLS workforce, termination of state, tribal, and museum grants, and the statutory requirement that IMLS award and manage federal grants and conduct data collection under the Museum and Library Services Act (MLS Act).

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: We extracted all key facts from the summary, including the lawsuit filing, the conversion of the airport into a detention center, the lack of NEPA review, the environmental context, the court orders, and the appellate proceedings.
